Adding @justinburke FYI.

Just to make sure, this is for comparing the security connector for subchannels of the same channel, and not across channel?

Can you please indicate in which case you would share a subchannel?

The main intent of the subchannel index is actually to share subchannels across channels.  In other words, if you have two channels whose name resolutions both include a given address, the subchannel for that address should be shared between the two channels, as long as all of the subchannel's channel args are the same.  (The security connector is a channel arg, so if the two channels have different credentials, the subchannel should not be shared.)

In practice, this mechanism is also used in a few other places to check the identify of a subchannel.  For example, the place where I noticed this problem is in the pick_first update code, where we get an updated list of addresses from the resolver and we need to check whether the address that we were previously using is still present in the new list.  Currently, due to the fact that the security connectors always compare non-equal, the pick_first code always winds up thinking that the original subchannel is not present in the new list, even when it is, which causes us to unnecessarily reconnect to the server.  This PR fixes that problem.

Note that historically, our code has always shared subchannels between channels; it has only been broken since #9194.  This PR simply restores the original behavior.

I'm wondering if there's not a better way: like keeping a reference of the
creds that create the connector and comparing the creds (maybe with a
simple pointer comparison). This would allow us to be more generic and to
keep all this code in gRPC without going to the TSI layer

On Mon, Oct 9, 2017 at 9:19 AM, Mark D. Roth <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> *@markdroth* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/core/lib/security/transport/security_connector.c
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/12767#discussion_r143515255>:
>
> > @@ -637,6 +686,26 @@ static void ssl_server_check_peer(grpc_exec_ctx *exec_ctx,
>    GRPC_CLOSURE_SCHED(exec_ctx, on_peer_checked, error);
>  }
>
> +static int ssl_channel_cmp(grpc_security_connector *sc1,
> +                           grpc_security_connector *sc2) {
> +  grpc_ssl_channel_security_connector *c1 =
> +      (grpc_ssl_channel_security_connector *)sc1;
> +  grpc_ssl_channel_security_connector *c2 =
> +      (grpc_ssl_channel_security_connector *)sc2;
> +  int c = grpc_channel_security_connector_cmp(&c1->base, &c2->base);
> +  if (c != 0) return c;
>
> I've added incomplete comparison functions for the SSL handshaker
> factories. The thing that's still missing is a way to compare the SSL_CTX
> objects, and I'm hoping you can help me with that, because I'm not very
> familiar with the OpenSSL API. Is there an easy way to do this? I did a
> quick websearch but didn't come up with anything, so I'm hoping you can
> suggest something. The only alternative I can think of is to save our own
> copy of the parameters that we use to construct the SSL_CTX object, but
> that seems like a waste of memory, so I'm hoping that there's a better way.
>
> â€”

> .

Right. Sorry I missed that.

On Oct 11, 2017 07:32, "Mark D. Roth" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *@markdroth* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/core/lib/http/httpcli_security_connector.cc
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/12767#discussion_r144029910>:
>
> > @@ -132,6 +132,10 @@ static grpc_security_status httpcli_ssl_channel_security_connector_create(
>      *sc = NULL;
>      return GRPC_SECURITY_ERROR;
>    }
> +  // We don't actually need a channel credentials object in this case,
> +  // but we set it to a non-NULL address so that we don't trigger
> +  // assertions in grpc_channel_security_connector_cmp().
> +  c->base.channel_creds = (grpc_channel_credentials *)1;
>
> No, because we're not doing that anywhere for the
> httpcli_ssl_channel_security_connector. If we had a real credentials
> object in this case, this line is the point at which we would be reffing
> it, and we'd be unreffing it in httpcli_ssl_destroy(). Neither of those
> things are happening, so this is not an issue.
>
> â€”
